column11: Often indescribable in its natural beauty, Nilaveli in its many moods is unparalleled in Sri Lanka. As it was the monsoon season, there were very few visitors, except at weekends when crowds of Sri Lankans arrived in buses to spend the day, bathing and partying, which was a lot of fun as everyone was so friendly.  There's a little lane of shops and cafes behind the beach where everyone gathered to buy toys, sweets and street food,  though it was closed during the week due to lack of visitors.  Most people stay in the lifeguard area, but I enjoy beach walks, so several times I walked a few kilometres southwards, and had it all to myself.  During the monsoon season the sea can be very rough, so it's almost impossible to swim as the current is so dangerous.  Most of the local visitors just stood in the water, in all their clothes!  I expect the beach would be totally different in the tourist season, probably with sunbeds etc., but I liked it as it was, wild and wonderful!
